Woody_Lee:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Woody Lee | image = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | birth_place = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|04|01}}{{Cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=237|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} | origin = [[Garland, Texas]], United States | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1994–1996 | label = [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] | associated_acts = [[Tracy Lawrence]] | website = }} '''Woody Lee''' (born April 1, 1968) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Signed to [[Atlantic Records]] in 1995, he released his debut album ''Get Over It'' that year. It produced the double-sided single "Get Over It"/"I Like the Sound of That." Before the release of his album, he co-wrote "[[I See It Now (song)|I See It Now]]" for fellow labelmate [[Tracy Lawrence]].{{Cite web|last=John |first=Bush |title=Woody Lee biography |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p144202/biography|pure_url=yes}} |work=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=June 15, 2009}} He also wrote [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]]'s 1995 single "Always Have, Always Will". ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:16em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Get Over It''{{cite magazine|url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1995/BB-1995-06-24.pdf|title=Album Reviews|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|page=62|date=June 24, 1995}} | * Release date: May 23, 1995 * Label: [[Atlantic Records]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:22em;"| Single ! colspan="1"| Peak chart
positions ! rowspan="2"| Album |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]
